On Thu, 02 Sep 2004 12:31:37 +0100, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@...> wrote: 
> This is great!
> 
> Does the net have any input to tell it how far zoomed it is?

Yeah...the network has inputs indicating its x and y position, zoom
factor, and rotation.

> How do you decide when the network has reached a decision?

We've tried some different approaches to this.  At first we just took
the affinity output value from the last time step.  This didn't work
extremely well.  In Floreano's work, they took the mean of the output
values for all time steps (they gave their networks 100 steps, we base
the number of steps given on the size and efficiency of the network). 
But that approach means that you're averaging in affinity values from
very early on process, before the network has really had a chance to
do any analysis, so the fitness is always going to be well below
optimal, even if the network correctly identifies the pattern.  So we
use a weighted average, skewing the affinity output values toward the
later steps and minimizing the impact of the affinity values in the
early steps.

Derek
